subjectDescription: Discover a full suite of online business courses that will allow you to make better business decisions and succeed in today's competitive business world. Our courses provide a rich learning experience that will allow you to develop critical business skills in areas such as business... Read more...
title: Fundamentals of Fundraising: How to Secure Funds for Your Business
headline: Learn how to start and grow your business by executing practical fundraising strategies in this free online course.
description: Do you have a great business idea but lack the financial capacity to execute it? Unfortunately, many great ideas are buried simply because these visionaries could not access the funds to launch their business concepts. To that end, the fundraising strategies presented in this online course will come in handy if you are searching for unique and practical fundraising techniques to start up and grow the business of your dreams.
courseDescription:
To make money, you require money. You may have heard this statement often but were likely unmoved by the expression. Imagine you have a great business idea but, faced with the reality of this saying, you find it impossible to start implementing your plans. So what now? Should you forget your business idea and let it go? Absolutely not! This course will provide you with all the information needed to secure funding for all of your business plans.

From the very first topic of the course, you will learn about starting your business using the resources already available to you. We call this concept ‘bootstrapping’: the process of selling the initial version of your business idea to get started. Subsequent topics in the course will explain how crowdfunding and business loans can be helpful and how to fully - yet safely - tap into the benefits of these fundraising avenues.

What if you are uncomfortable with the thought of taking a loan to avoid debt? Rest assured, there are alternatives available! The option is finding an investor to fund your business based on agreed terms. In this course, you will learn how to acquire the required funding without going into debt successfully. So what are you waiting for? Discover the many fundraising techniques and start this course to initiate your dream business successfully.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital : a downloadable in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • : a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked , posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed : a physical version of your officially branded and security marked in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

All are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison , please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison , you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our pricing, please visit our Pricing Page
slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Explain the concept of bootstrapping.
    • Compute the financial records of your business.
    • Distinguish between crowdfunding, microloan, traditional loan, and investment.
    • List the major components of a loan package.
    • Outline the different sections of a presentation deck.
    • Recognize the risks involved in running a company and how they may be addressed.

  • Case Study

  • Imagine your friend, Henry, loves football. He knows all the major players and their stats, watches all the games, and has decorated his house in a football theme.

    Henry tells you that he’s started taking football lessons, and his coach thinks he has the potential to be a professional player one day.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • He decides to enter some competitions. Knowing that Henry just started football lessons 6 months ago and has never been in a football tournament before, what type of competition do you think he should enter?
  • Question: Which tournament should Henry choose as his first competition?
    • A world championship tournament where he’ll face the best-known players.
    • A national tournament for experienced professionals.
    • A local tournament with amateurs and novices.

  • Elements for Business Success

  • For lots of people, starting a business can be exciting. You’ll get to do something that motivates you while hopefully making people happy. But there’s a lot that goes into starting a business.
    A good business plan, management skills, and proper funding each play an important part in getting the job done.

    With so many different elements needed for your business to thrive, it can be tough to know which is the most important.
    What can make the biggest difference between staying in business and closing up shop? Let’s find out.
  • Question: Which of these do you think is important in ensuring the success of a business?
    • A great business plan.
    • A strong management team.
    • Good source of funding.
    • All of the above.

  • Case Study

  • Picture Pearl, who owns a jewellery store. Business has been good, and she’s thinking about opening a second location.

    Pearl has saved up some money and created a strong business plan. Still, she knows that she’ll need more money to open her new spot.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Pearl doesn’t have a very strong social network or flashy marketing materials. She’s also not trying to create a business with millions of customers right now.

    She just wants to open another store. So what’s the best way for her to get funding?
    If you have access to a qualified lender–like a bank–and know you can make regular payments, a small business loan can be a great way to get funding.

    These loans are designed to help you grow your business. You can use the money to buy equipment and office supplies, pay employees, or purchase the raw materials you need.

    If you have access to a qualified lender–like a bank–and know you can make regular payments, a small business loan can be a great way to get funding.

    These loans are designed to help you grow your business. You can use the money to buy equipment and office supplies, pay employees, or purchase the raw materials you need.

  • Case Study

  • Picture Clyde, a young farmer who has developed a good reputation working for other people.
    Recently, his uncle left him a piece of land.

    It’s got great soil, and Clyde is thinking of starting his own small farm there, allowing him to produce for his family and his community.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • But while Clyde has the land and technical know-how, he can’t cover the value of some of the equipment he needs. The machines shouldn’t be too expensive, but their price tags stand between him and his goal of starting a business.

    Clyde hasn’t owned a business before and hasn’t established his credit. But he needs money, so he’s thinking of visiting a bank to get a loan.
    But could a traditional small business loan be right for him?

  • Case Study

  • Case Study

  • Imagine it’s 9:45 pm, and you’re craving a chocolate peanut butter pie. You preheat the oven, and get out your ingredients, but you remember you don't have eggs. You hurry to your neighbour’s house and ask to borrow the 2 eggs.
  • You and your neighbour are friendly, but not necessarily friends.

    So while she’ll give them to you, she’d like 2 of the 8 slices of that pie you’re making in return. You’re left wondering what to do.

    Stores are closed for the night, and you’re really in the mood to bake that delicious dessert. But if you take her eggs, you’ll have to give up 25% of your pie.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • What’s the most logical move? Would you take the deal and keep 75% of the pie or give up the deal and the pie? If you really want pies for the night, it would make sense to accept the offer.

  • Case Study

  • Case Study

  • Imagine Umar loses his umbrella so often that it gives him a business idea: a subscription service that sends customers a new umbrella every 3 months.

    Umar knows he’s not the only person who loses and needs to replace his umbrella repeatedly, so he knows there’s a decent market for his service.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • He’s even gathered a team and developed an early stage of the service to prove it works. 

    But as good as Umar’s idea is, and as scrappy and motivated as his team is, they need money to take their business to the next level and become a success.

    What does Umar need to think about before he starts asking around for money?

  • Case Study

  • Case Study

  • Imagine Bibiana runs a small online shop where she sells bike baskets that can be easily removed without tools and used as shopping baskets at the grocery store.

    Bibiana has perfected her product and has sold quite a few baskets, and she’s assembled a talented team who can help her build even better ones. 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • She has big dreams of getting her baskets on not just a few bikes but millions of them. Bibiana knows that to achieve her dream of being the baroness of baskets, she needs to book some meetings with investors.

    What could Bibiana share at those meetings to convince them to invest in her bike basket business? Let’s decide.

  • Case Study

  • She has big dreams of getting her baskets on not just a few bikes but millions of them. Bibiana knows that to achieve her dream of being the baroness of baskets, she needs to book some meetings with investors.

    What could Bibiana share at those meetings to convince them to invest in her bike basket business? Let’s decide.

  • Lesson Summary

  • In this course, you have learned that:
    • Bootstrapping is a way of starting and funding your business without taking out loans or relying on investors. This means you’re building your business using your own resources instead of getting outside financial support.
    • Strong management, a good source of funding, and a good business plan are important when starting a business.
    • Crowdfunding usually involves collecting lots of small sums from potential customers, your social network, friends, and family.
    • Microloans are small loans available from a variety of sources, including online loan platforms, community organizations, and nonprofit groups.
    • A loan package is a set of documents intended to help a lender understand exactly why you’re asking for a loan. It’s like a story that positions you as a reliable hero who can overcome business challenges.
    • You should have a clear idea of how long it will take for you to repay the loan you get, as well as how many years this loan will help your business.
